Fields.DialogueText: Baihao Yinzhen.
Gesundheit.
Silver needle, you philistine! It's hard to get from China these days, but I'm finding it indispensable lately.
It's certainly calming. That never goes amiss out here.
Indeed! It steeps at a fairly low temperature, too. That way you can drink it quickly if you're--
*ALARM*
Rudely interrupted?

Fields.MenuText: The Morganas have gone too far this time!
Did you not secure it before the battle?
Need some help?

Fields.DialogueText: I know when I'm being mocked!
I thought for certain I had. I'm usually so responsible about it...
I appreciate it, Captain, but I wouldn't make you do something so tedious.
Wait... what's that among the rooibos?
What's what? Oh, there's a piece of paper...
"That's for Scott. Your dearest sister, York."
Do you need a moment?
Several, Captain.
What kind of tea did you say this was, Exeter?
Got it in one. These Morganas have no respect for tea time.
@BATTLE
Another day, another victory! We're... oh, you cannot be serious.
Something wrong, Exeter?
My tea! It's spilled everywhere. Oh, these leaves will take hours to gather back up...
Captain, is that today's mail?
Exeter! I was just looking for you. You've got a letter from York.
Finally. I was getting impatient. Let's see...
...Right. As expected.
York apologized?
Her captain did, on behalf of her crew. It seems we need to switch again.
Is this a Belle thing?
An us thing, Captain. Well, a me thing. York hasn't awakened yet.
So you're spying on her?

Fields.MenuText: And Command is fine with it?
Are you honest with your guest?
Belles have sibling rivalry?

Fields.DialogueText: We never use crew in highly specialised roles. It'd be too disruptive otherwise.
I've already got two years of technological superiority on her. Deceit wouldn't be sporting.
Somehow it's even worse when you can quantify your differences.
That still doesn't explain the tea.
I'm afraid York's sailor took our rivalry a little too seriously. It's not a war.
And Scott?
@BATTLE
She's the elder sister, but I've the better design. But if she's anything like me, she'll have tricks up her sleeve.
So we swap crew on occasion and have them report on each other. I let York's crew aboard to keep it fair.
Long story, Captain. I'll tell you once we've beaten these Morganas. It looks like we're about to catch up to them...
Let me get this straight. Your favorite explorer is Ernest Shackleton.
He's the greatest, Captain! Three Antarctic expeditions fixes you pretty high in my esteem.
And York's favorite is Robert Scott.
Her ensign assumed so, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: And... that meant he had to destroy your tea?
Do you think he's right?
I've always been an admirer of his.

Fields.DialogueText: It doesn't make any sense to me either, Captain.
York and I aren't going to see eye to eye on many things, but I can't speak for personal preferences.
There is something to be said for reaching the South Pole...
Never heard of it.
Permission to boast, Captain?
Granted.
It sounds like a case of Nemo Syndrome.
We Belles are quite popular, to understate the matter. There are some whose interest goes beyond that of a mere fan.
... As in romantically, or-
Sometimes. Sometimes, as with York's ensign, they just impute their own fantasies and assumptions on us.
Miss Lexington named it, I believe. Some book or other she was reading...
You'd think Zurich would screen for this sort of thing.
There's so little you know about us. It's difficult to draw the line between theories and fantasies.
But to answer your forthcoming question, he's been dishonorably discharged. We're not going to have to worry about his kind slipping into our crew.
I thought that wasn't possible to check for.
Not yet, Captain. I've got a few ideas percolating...
Uh-oh.
Focus on the Morganas for now, Captain. And don't worry. I'm not like some of my more... unconventional sisters.
@BATTLE
Finally. I think that's the very last of the tea leaves picked up.
Your dedication is... something.
I'm not going to waste good tea, Captain! Who knows when I'll get my hands on more?

Fields.MenuText: Isn't there something more useful you could be doing?
You could always requisition some from Zurich.
I don't blame you. The world's about to get a lot more dangerous.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly why we cannot rest, Captain!
I believe in minimizing waste, Captain. Even if it does get a bit tedious.
Given that I know when we're due to intercept the enemy, and my hull and guns are spotless... probably not. I budget my time very carefully indeed.
I suppose I should consider myself lucky. Some of the other Belles would have made their crew do this.
Some of the other Belles are megalomaniacal and cruel. I am neither! But that doesn't mean I don't have plans for my crew.
Growing their own tea?
Captain, of course not! We don't stay in any of the proper latitudes for nearly long enough.
Sure. That's the problem.
You think I haven't dreamed about that since I awoke? No, Captain, you'll find my plans much more constructive.
*ALARM*
I'll put it this way. When was the last time you wrote a letter home?
On a different but related subject, where are you from?
Me? Oh, I'm from-
No time for that, Exeter. We've got Morganas.
Well, think on it, won't you? It may be the key to our little fan problem.
@BATTLE
Help me with this crate, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: What's the cargo?
Secret weapons?
Got some contraband to declare?

Fields.DialogueText: I'll tell you all about it over a cuppa tonight.
Don't need those to succeed!
Caught me, Captain! It's loaded with bombs.
Almost there... all right, stop. If you brace it against-
Right, the bulkhead there. Takes the load off and... brilliant. All right, we'll get that unpacked within the-
I'm flattered, Exeter, but that crate is bigger than you are.
Silly! You can spot for me. I wanted to handle this one personally. Just need to get it nearer to a hatch.
*ALARM*
Cachu hwch. If this gets blown up, I'm going to be extremely put out.
We'll have to be careful, then. These seas have been volatile lately.
Within reason. These are just things... even if they cost a pretty penny.
Seriously, what did you requisition?
Something the whole crew can share, Captain. Ought to help us on those long voyages.
Extra rum rations?
Oh, use your imagination!
@BATTLE
What's your typing speed?
60, 65 WPM or so.
Hmm. Quicker than I would have guessed.
Looking for a biographer?
Bit early for that, isn't it?

Fields.MenuText: You were born in '31. That's some years under your belt.

Fields.DialogueText: For anyone who wants to read about refits and a very boring life in the Caribbean. Look, we're getting off topic.
The crew got all the typewriters and ink unloaded. I was curious.
So that's what was rattling around in that crate.

Fields.MenuText: Belle years are a lot more eventful than human years.

Fields.DialogueText: Depends on the human, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: You'd better recruit me before your sister wakes up and steals me.

Fields.DialogueText: Honestly, Captain! She's not going to be that tactless... I think.
Chalk that up to a packing error. One of the machines took a beating in transit, poor thing.
Training an army of stenographers?
Look at it this way, Captain. That one ensign from York, remember him? Who smashed my tearoom because he thought my sister would have wanted it?
He torpedoed his career because of some idiotic sibling rivalry fantasy. What's that got to do with us?
That fantasy mattered to him for... whatever reason. I thought I'd encourage the crew to write home, write to friends. It might help to keep them grounded.
It might help if everyone knew everyone else was doing it. A little solidarity never goes amiss.
Exactly! I'm so glad you understand.
Damn. We're on track to engage Morganas or I'd pry a little more.
Precisely what I'm trying to encourage! This will be such a help.
@BATTLE
How's the typing coming?

Fields.MenuText: If only you could erase when you mistyped.
Well, keep at it. I'm sure they're eager to learn from you.
Which ones?

Fields.DialogueText: If only! Some of their letters have looked like treasure maps. With lots of treasure, if you get my meaning.
I'm good for more than blowing up Morganas. If I can help them in a fight, I can help them out of one.
Not telling. Some of them are used to different keyboards, at any rate. It's not their fault.
As long as they get their letters written, I suppose.
They'll pick it up.
*ALARM*
Damn! Almost flawless.
Sounds like motive for vengeance, Captain!
Frustrating. It's been a while since I really sat down and did this.
Did... did you type all this just now? I only left you about an hour ago.
When I said 60-65 WPM, I might have understated. They take words off for mistakes.
I might make a teacher of you yet! Progress with some of the crew has been... halting.
Which, like writing, is better when shared.
Meet you on the bridge!
@BATTLE
Is that from York, Captain?
Yes, actually. Captain to captain.
Ah! Of course.
You're welcome to read it. It concerns you, after all.
Hmm... Interesting. What do you think, Captain?
York's captain asks a compelling question. Is there some kind of common reason for you Belles awakening?
Not that I know of, Captain. We're all different, but a lot of us awoke during combat.
The first one did, didn't she?
Karl Galster! They say she was first seen when a Morgana blew her boiler. She walked out of the explosion, returned fire, and only stopped when the danger had passed.

Fields.MenuText: I wish I could have been there to see it.
If only the Germans hadn't gotten Belles first.
What about you?

Fields.DialogueText: Who knows how much truth there is to it? Although the image is stirring...
I don't like it any more than you, Captain. But don't forget I was the second of my class. I turned out all right.
... Less impressive, Captain. I scared hell out of the radio room when I walked in and offered them tea. That's the first thing I remember.
There's really no way to predict these things, though. I get feelings and visions from time to time... vague ideas about who she might be.
But we awake when the time is right. No sooner.
*ALARM*
Morganas, on the other hand...
@BATTLE
Gwrachod. I take it York's captain's sending someone new, then?
Someone he says is less... passionate. We'll see how that shakes out.
The crew swap's gone off without a hitch.
Mechanics and laborers, usually. They can fill in fairly seamlessly.
And here I thought our patrols were adjacent for strategic reasons.
Don't look at me like that, Captain. It was her idea.
I thought she hadn't awakened yet.
Well, I don't want to take the credit. There was this dream, you see...

Fields.MenuText: We can't run a war on dreams.
The visions you mentioned?
Is York awake or isn't she?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, exactly. Between you and me, it's easier with only one sister. I can only imagine the cacophony the girls in the larger classes have to listen to.
She's not. But that doesn't mean I can't hear her.
I'm still not following.
I wish I could explain it better, Captain. She's in there somewhere, in her guns and her hull and her engines. She just hasn't figured out how to communicate the way I have.
Zurich needed heavy cruisers and they got heavy cruisers, Captain. We're allowed to make suggestions between the lines.
And you did?
... Point. It's not like I had to learn it.
So you can talk to her.
Not the way you and I talk. All I know is that she wants to be ready for the fight. And ready for me.
As ready as anyone can be for you Belles.
You seem to be doing all right.
Thank you, Exeter.
Thank me later, Captain. I'm sensing Morganas. York's man had better take notes!
@BATTLE
Exeter, are we going to have to requisition more milk? I just can't find-

Fields.MenuText: You're not telling me your sister told you to do this.
It's between you and the signalman.
Is there something wrong with York?

Fields.DialogueText: No, Captain, I'm not telling you.
Wait! I should have phrased that better.
Not York herself, Captain.
Iesu Grist!
What the- Exeter, what's wrong?
N-nothing! Nothing you need worry about! You just... daioni, have you always been so quiet?
What's that you've got behind your back?
I... Captain, I can't lie to you. This is from Signalman Nkemdiche to his wife back in Bristol.
You're reading the crew's mail!?
I can explain! The-
*ALARM*
After these Morganas are done with, I'm coming for you.
Yes, Captain.
@BATTLE
Explain. Whether I like your explanation determines whether Signalman Nkemdiche hears it.
It's... It's all to do with my sister, Captain.
I've been feeling... strange things from York.
Qualify that.
The visions I get from her are... scared. Confused. Like she's trapped somewhere, or... trying to hide.
What's that got to do with invading our crew's privacy?
This isn't normal for her, Captain. The only thing I can think of that's changed is...
Her crew.
Or my crew, on loan to her.
Whatever's going on, this isn't going to be solved by what you're doing. It stops now.
Captain-
That's an order.
Yes, Captain.
I apologized to Signalman Nkemdiche, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: That's between you and him.
What more was there to understand?
Mhm.

Fields.DialogueText: You're my captain. There are certain things that have to be shared between us.
I know it was wrong, but the situation was extraordinary.
Captain, I'm arriving at a point here.
Good.
He said he understood.
I'm a little busy at the moment, Exeter.
None of this happened until after the most recent crew swap. The one variable that changed is the makeup of the crew.
So for the sake of argument, let's say that someone aboard you is giving York nightmares. How are you going to get to the bottom of this by reading their mail?
However they're doing it, they're not just going to tell me!
What are you looking for, exactly? "Dearest wife, I've been whispering poison into the dreams of a heavy cruiser?"
That heavy cruiser is my sister and I will not see her harmed!
*ALARM*
You want to help your sister? Drive these Morganas out of these waters. With any luck they'll be too damaged to pay a visit.
Dos i chwalu peipan gachu dy daid...
@BATTLE
Tea, Captain?
This the Bauhaus stuff?
Baihao, Captain. Honestly, get a bit of culture in you.
Did we ever end up requisitioning more milk?
Take this straight or it's ruined. Captain, I feel an apology is needed.

Fields.MenuText: You've already apologized to Signalman Nkemdiche.
For?
I'm waiting.

Fields.DialogueText: This is bigger than him, or anyone else's mail I've read.
I wasn't honest about this whole letter thing to begin with.
Brace yourself, Captain. It's a bit... well.
Look, before we go on... you don't have to be afraid to apologize.
It's... a problem of motive, Captain. The truth is I started the whole letter thing to cover up my spying on York. Or, well... on her crew... whoever's disturbing her sleep.
I've never been afraid of anything in my life.
No, but I can see you feel bad. It's not my job to make it worse.
Anyone else's?
As I was saying...
You really feel strongly about this, don't you?
Just put yourself in my shoes, Captain. If you had family who were hurting, you'd do anything to find out why and make it stop.
I couldn't just do it without raising suspicion. But along the way I decided... if I can use this to help people, it might shake out okay after all.
I may not have liked your methods at first, Exeter. But your heart's clearly in the right place.
Here's a deal. Respect the crew's privacy from here on. Meanwhile, I'll look into York's service record and see if there's anything... off.
I think I can work with that. Thank you, Captain.
Now, as for this tea-
And I'm sorry I told you to go break your grandfather's bagpipe.
... Exeter, what does that even-
Oh, uffern... Morganas, Captain!
@BATTLE
For you, Captain.
Oh? What's this?
Roman coin, Captain. People send me loads from home.
Plymouth?
That's where I was born, but I consider Exeter my home. These are all over the place from Roman Britain.
You must have a lot of fans back home.
Yes, well. One of these days I'll find a way to give back.

Fields.MenuText: Your service speaks for itself.
What did you have in mind?
Maybe send them some of your scrap from after a fight.

Fields.DialogueText: Ordinarily I'm content to let it. But it wouldn't hurt to find my people something nice from abroad.
Something similar. Old, formerly valuable, brimming with history...
Ugh! No, thank you, Captain. Some Belles might, but for me it'd be like sending fingernails or skin.
But I think I'll start with my crew. And you.
For keepsakes?
As a promise, Captain. Hold on to this coin and know I won't betray your trust.
Let's make this work both ways. Aboard another ship or on shore, these will be a sign that we serve aboard you.
Works for me.
*ALARM*
Morganas. I'll keep this in my breast pocket. Should protect me from shrapnel.
It'll have to get through me first!
@BATTLE
All right, everyone, clear out! The Morganas could be anywhere. Thank you for sharing your stories.
Throwing a luncheon?
Captain! You just missed it. The crew and I were going over some of their letters together.
What do you mean, going over them? Like proofreading?
A little copy editing, a little content editing. And discussion thereof.

Fields.MenuText: Didn't I tell you to stay out of their business?
There's more to it than that.
I never took you for the loophole type.

Fields.DialogueText: One of the radiomen asked me specifically, Captain.
She thought it might foster support among the crew. Military mail is reliable, but everyone needs someone to talk to... at some times more than others.
It's rough enough out here without the specter of Morganas to deal with. This isn't mandatory, I take it?
Not everyone needs it. Not everyone wants it. But if and when that changes, anyone's welcome to join or not.
Hmm. All right, Exeter. If the crew are in favor, I'm all for it.
I'm glad you understand, Captain! This really will do wonders for morale.
Trust is a powerful thing. It might just be powerful enough to win us some battles.
Both on the seas and off.
Oh, speaking of communication... any news from York's captain?
I've written to him, but haven't heard back.
Of course, Captain. I was talking to one of the radiomen when she gave me the idea.
That's not it at all, Captain. I hadn't even thought of this until one of the radiomen asked.
Poke him again if he doesn't soon.
You can't?
Our crew swap's a known quantity. I'd rather not push too hard until I know where it's safe to.
Uffern... Action stations, Captain. I'm sensing some witches who aren't afraid to do some pushing of their own.
@BATTLE
I see you lurking, Captain! All you need do is ask to join.
I was just passing by the mess, honest.
I believe you, Captain.
So what's the conversation like today?
Classified. It's between me and those who choose to attend.

Fields.MenuText: I respect that.
And if I choose to attend?
Some captains wouldn't appreciate clandestine meetings.

Fields.DialogueText: That's all I ask.
It'll be because you want to be heard, Captain. Trust me.
It's good to blow off steam now and again. Reminds me of my trip to the Meditarranean, in a way.
Some Belles chafe at hierarchy and scheme at every turn. I just want to help.
I thought you'd spent most of your time in the Caribbean.
The Italians got up to some ffolineb in Ethiopia a few years back. Nothing came my way, ultimately, but the change of scenery was nice.
Hmm. A precaution, then.
More or less.
That's actually what I wanted to talk to you about.
Uffern... it'll have to wait, Captain. I dismissed the crew to action stations from our meeting. Looks like my instinct was right.
@BATTLE
Glad that's over. We're lucky we had some overlap with York's group.
I did finally hear back from her captain.
Oh! What does he say?
Not to worry about York - she's doing splendidly, he says.
York is. The sleeping York.
Right.
Not her crew.
... Huh. Now that you mention it, I don't think he... ah.
Exeter, do me a favor. Listen a little harder next time you dream?
Right there with you, Captain. I've got a bad feeling about this.
Rough session?
Rough session.
I saw a few of the crew leaving arm in arm. Looks like you were on to something.
It really does help, Captain. There were a few more than last time... word is spreading.
What about York?
... More complex.

Fields.MenuText: Is she in danger?
The more I learn about you Belles, the less I feel like I know.
What does she say?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm afraid for her, Captain.
Sometimes I feel that way too, Captain.
It's not what she says, Captain. It's what she doesn't say.
If you could only feel what I feel when I sleep... when I choose to sleep. Fire... confusion...
How did she fare in her last engagement?
Bad. The Morganas came this close to her torpedo magazine. If that had gone...
Boom.
Have you ever been somewhere where you didn't know the rules? Or where you did, but you knew something was terribly wrong?
That's war.
That's a prison, Captain! It's being shuffled from place to place and held up as a sacrifice when you know you could be...
Oh, Duw. Captain, that's it.
*ALARM*
I'll explain after the battle. We'll need to sit down for this.
@BATTLE
Exeter, I think you and I are seeing eye to eye about this.
You think it's him?
I'm not sure. I'll have to go over the letters again. It'll be in the way he talks about her.
*ALARM*
You know what I'm referring to.
Nemo syndrome.

Fields.MenuText: I'm still not a hundred percent certain.
That Belle intuition, eh?
I can't believe I didn't see it before.

Fields.DialogueText: Who else could it be?
Yours matches.
Sometimes the answer's right beside you, helping you look for it.
You remember when we talked about Belles awakening, Captain?
I remember when York's captain asked about it. He's brought it up in almost every correspondence since then.
To think that someone could try and force one of my sisters awake...
Forgive me if this is an insensitive question... is that possible?
No, Captain. Never. We know what can wake us up. It doesn't mean we know what will.
Not to hear York's captain tell it.
@BATTLE
If we've both reached this conclusion, there has to be some truth to it.
I've heard her, Captain. She's being steered closer, kept within enemy range longer, run further and further up against her limits.
It could very well break her, Captain. And her entire crew could go down with her.
I've heard enough. Effective immediately, I'm recalling our spy from York.
Captain, no! If anything changes suddenly - if York's captain feels time is running out - who knows what he might do?
All the more reason not to risk the lives of my men.
We're playing with the life of my sister!
Her captain is. We are not getting caught up in it until we can present our case to Zurich and the Admiralty.
... Cachu.
Those coins have really caught on with the crew.
It's encouraging, Captain. It's nice to know someone trusts you.
What am I supposed to do? Keep my men somewhere we both know is dangerous?
No, Captain, you're right. I just hate waiting.
Have you talked to any of the crew about it?

Fields.MenuText: You let them share their stories with you.
They wouldn't get it?
You don't think they could be spying?

Fields.DialogueText: When they want to, Captain. There are one or two people who've barely talked. That's their prerogative. That's mine.
Not the way my captain would.
I know our crew, Captain. None of them have it in them.
I'm glad you can at least talk to me about it.
I'm glad you do. It's because I know you'd understand that I feel...
That's it!
What?
*ALARM*
Get to the bridge. I'll explain on the way.
@BATTLE
I don't know that I have the patience for your plan, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: We don't have much of a choice, do we?
Do you have the resolve?
Do you trust me?

Fields.DialogueText: There's always a choice.
If it comes to it... yes. It better not.
Implicitly. That's why it's eating at me.
Why do the people in your sessions talk?
Because they feel they're in a safe environment for it.
Because everyone is there to listen. Not to judge.
So you're saying if you keep York's captain talking he'll spill the beans.
When you're passionate about something, don't you want to share it with all your heart?
I hate even describing such an obsession that way.
But you know what I'm talking about. I don't like it any more than you do, but your sister may be exactly where she needs to be right now.
We're patrolling within range of her for a reason today, Captain. I have to be right where she needs me.
*ALARM*
You may get your wish, Exeter.
Os gwelwch yn dda... Hold out just a little longer.
@BATTLE
Mail's here.
... Exeter?
I've been dreaming again, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: York?
Tell me she's all right.
We're too late.

Fields.DialogueText: York.
I... I don't know.
Na! We're not. We can't be.
Do you want to talk about it?
I can't just yet, Captain. It's...
Point me at something I can destroy. I need this.
@BATTLE
I think I'm ready.
What did you see?
Shadows, Captain. It was all murky and chaotic. The things I listen for to know she's there just almost... weren't.
That letter from her captain might shed some light on things.
What happened on that last patrol?
She's floating. They can fix her. But they almost-
What did her captain say?
"... She continues to outdo herself. If there is a limit, I have yet to find it. But I will. Mark my words."
...Ffiaidd. Captain.
Exeter?
You've done your part for my sister. Now let me do mine.
Have you filled in the crew on what's happening today?
They know we're near York's patrol group. We're prepared to intervene as necessary.
Do they know about your stake in  it?
My stake, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: You have a sister to save.
You haven't told them?
This isn't some kind of altruistic gesture.

Fields.DialogueText: I do. And the world also has another defender to prepare the way for.
Not explicitly. But some of them can guess.
Does it have to be all one way or the other?
You know the risks.
The same as any other battle, Captain. We just have a different objective.
I realize that. But Exeter, if at any point we have to choose between York and you-
-We save me. I'm the known quantity. York isn't. Not to any human authority. There is still the mission to consider.
I know how heartless it seems. You're more than just weapons.
Exactly. If I fail to protect her, or have to put her down... it will be as a sister. Not as a cruiser. I'm prepared to carry that within my soul.
Looks like we're coming up on them. Are you ready?
Like her hull was my own.
@BATTLE
Her captain's been recalled, Exeter. It's over.
Diolch i Dduw.

Fields.MenuText: Thank Zurich for seeing reason.
That's more right than you know.
That was your moment, Exeter. You made the most of it.

Fields.DialogueText: I do. But a little help from the Almighty never goes amiss.
We couldn't have done it without you.
Thank you, Captain. I wouldn't be a very good sister if I didn't.
I'm honored to have captained you through it.
-He would have turned himself in anyway.
Please. If you hadn't been building up a dossier thicker than my shield-
Captain! Is it true what they're saying? Did he-
He... he what? Just like that?
I got one more letter from him after that last fight.
What did it say?
The truth. Everything he thought he could bring out in York, by whatever means necessary... he saw in you.
It's like you said. You're more than just a ship. You're family. Seeing you take those hits meant for her... I think it would have been a wake-up call for anyone.
Hmph. I still would have loved to spring the trap on him.
Believe me, any longer and I would have contemplated assassinating him.
Captain!
His prose was that bad.
You're awful, Captain!
... And you're also indispensable. I would do anything for my sister. But it did help to know I had someone fighting by my side.
Shall we do it again?
With pride!
@BATTLE
Savor this cup, Captain. We're coming down to the last of it.
I'm going to miss this boohoo stuff.
Now you're just doing it on purpose.

Fields.MenuText: Bighead, sorry.
I'll get it right someday.
It's just tea.

Fields.DialogueText: That's it. This tea's wasted on you.
See that you do, Captain. My stash has been through enough!
Never took you for a blasphemer.
I'll tell you what, though. I might take you up on your offer one of these days.
To join in on our sessions? We'd love to have you there.
It might be nice to just be who I am for an hour out of the day. Like you were with York.
There's something to be said for speaking from the heart.
Or shooting from there.
I'm serious, Captain. It makes me wonder if York's captain or her crewman couldn't have used a chat.
You're the last person I'd expect to hear pity them.
I'm not defending their actions at all. But people do strange things when they're alone with their thoughts. When there's no one to bounce them off of-
-Or to slap some sense into you.
Or that. People are uncommonly good at convincing themselves of the strangest things.
Like your sibling rivalry.
Oh, it's going to happen one way or another, Captain. But tea is sacred. My sister will know that.
A shame the Morganas don't.
As good an excuse as any to send them packing!
@BATTLE
Need a spotter again?
Oh, Captain, that'd be lovely! I just need to set this down... ah! Got it.
That's even bigger than the last one.

Fields.MenuText: Showoff.
I'm glad you're on our side.
Seriously?

Fields.DialogueText: I can't be humble all the time, Captain.
Oh, you'd find a way around us eventually. Humans are brilliant at that.
My shield's a real anghenfil, Captain. One gets used to heavy objects.
Really? I hadn't noticed.
Should I be concerned about what's in the box?
Be odd if you weren't, Captain. It does concern you.
For me?
A gift, Captain. A bit of the old hometown to seal the covenant between us. I trust you with this as with my life.
I'm honored, Exeter.
Pleased to honour you.
Which brings us to my previous question...
Exeter Cathedral was kind enough to spare one of her bells. A victory bell, if you will. For a victorious Belle - and her steadfast captain.
Don't those things-
Weigh a couple of tons? You don't have to tell me that, Captain.
That's... some gift. Thank... um, thank you.
*ALARM*
Is this going to be safe?
Ought to be. Let's make double sure, shall we?
@BATTLE
There's an extra bounce in your step today, Exeter.

Fields.MenuText: Then it's enough for me too.
Something tells me we have a lot more than that in common.

Fields.DialogueText: I've waited this long. Now I know I can wait a little more.
Oh, she's going to adore you, Captain. Runs in the family, don't you know?
You won't believe it, Captain. If I tell you now I'm going to talk right through this engagement.
Such a tease. The Morganas must be taking notes.
They'd better, Captain. Otherwise there will be no dragons left to slay!
@BATTLE
Are you going to tell me or are you going to keep vibrating?
I've had another dream, Captain.
York?
I didn't just see her this time, Captain. I didn't just feel her. I heard her.
Out loud? As in with words? Exeter, that's amazing!
She's not quite patched up to her old self yet. But she's a hell of a fighter. She'll be good as new in no time.
I'd expect nothing less of someone related to you. What did she say?
"Soon."
Just "soon?"
It's enough for me, Captain.
They talk when they're ready, eh? Sounds like some crew we know.
We're not so different, I and they. Or you and I. Or she and we.
